body.p: This page describes the configuration of HP 3PAR StoreServ Fibre Channel (FC) or iSCSI storage devices as a Cinder backend. Once the backend is configured you can create and validate the volume.

ul.li: HP Helion Cloud must be successfully deployed. It should be up and running.
3PAR should available in cloud management network or routed to cloud management network with FC and iSCSI ports configured.
3PAR management IP and iSCSI port IP's must have connectivity from controller and compute nodes.

section.title: Configure 3PAR FC as Cinder backend
section.p: You must modify cinder.conf.j2 to configure FC details.

Perform the following steps to configure 3PAR FC as Cinder backend:
Login to deployer node.
Change the directory as shown below:cd ~/helion
Edit cinder.conf.j2 file at hos/ansible/roles/_CND-CMN/templates/cinder.conf.j2 to add 3PAR FC data as follows:enabled_backends=3par_FCAppend this change with the exiting backend, if you have already added VSA as backend.
Copy 3PAR FC section, uncomment it, and modify the values in the cinder.conf.j2 file as shown in the following example:[3par_FC] hp3par_api_url=https://10.1.192.10:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=helionadmin hp3par_password=helion hp3par_cpg=FC_r5,FC_r1 san_ip=10.1.192.10 san_login=helionadmin san_password=helion volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_fc.HP3PARFCDriver volume_backend_name=3par_FC Please enter the values which are specific to your environment.
Commit your configuration to a local repository:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "<commit message>" Enter your commit message <commit message>
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Change the directory to ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible and run the following command to create a deployment directory.ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

section.title: Configure 3PAR iSCSI as Cinder backend
section.p: You must modify cinder.conf.j2 to configure iSCSI details.

ol.li: Change the directory as shown below:cd ~/helion

Edit cinder.conf.j2 file at /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/config/cinder to enable 3PAR FC as follows:enabled_backends=3par_iSCSIAppend this change with the exiting backend, if you have already added VSA as backend.

Copy 3PAR iSCSI section, uncomment it, and modify the values in the cinder.conf.j2 file as shown in the following example:[3par_iSCSI] hp3par_api_url=https://10.1.192.10:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=helionadmin hp3par_password=helion hp3par_cpg=FC_r1 san_ip=10.1.192.10 san_login=helionadmin san_password=helion volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver volume_backend_name=3par_iSCSI iscsi_ip_address=172.32.0.9 hp3par_iscsi_chap_enabled=true Please enter the values of all the paramters specific to your environment.
Execute the steps (5 -7) mentioned in Configure 3PAR FC as Cinder backend and Run Cinder Reconfigure Packages as mentioned above.

section.title: Create Volume Type to Verify the Configuration of 3PAR FC and iSCSI
section.p: You must create a volume type to verify the configuration of 3PAR FC and iSCSI. Once you are able to create the volume then delete the created volume.
Perform the following steps to create a volume type using Horizon dashboard:

ol.li: Log into the Horizon dashboard as Admin. The Horizon dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Admin tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Click Create Volume Type to display a dialog box.
Enter a unique name for the volume.

Click Create Volume Type to complete the action. Clicking Cancel returns to the Volumes screen without completing the action.
The newly created volume displays in the Volumes page.

body.section:
Associate the Volume Type to a Backend
To map a volume type to a backend, do the following:
Login to the Horizon dashboard. The Horizon dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Admin tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Click View Extra Specs displayed against the volume type which you want to associate to the backend.
The Create Volume Type Extra Specs dialog box displays. Now map the volume type to the associate backend.
For 3PAR FC
In the Key box, enter volume_backend_name as volume backend name. This is the name of the key used to specify the storage backend when provisioning volumes of this volume type. The volume backend name must match the backend name mentioned in the cinder.conf file. For example: 3par_fc
In the Value box, enter the name of the backend to which you want to associate the volume type. For example:helion_3par_fc.
For 3PAR iSCSI
In the Key box, enter volume_backend_name as volume backend name. This is the name of the key used to specify the storage backend when provisioning volumes of this volume type. The volume backend name must match the backend name mentioned in the cinder.conf file. For Example: 3par_iscsi.
In the Value box, enter the name of the backend to which you want to associate the volume type. For example:helion_3par_iscsi.
Click Create to create the extra volume type specs. Once the volume type is mapped to the backend, you can create volumes with this volume type. Once the Admin has performed the above operations, you can login as a user and create a volume.

section.p:
Perform the following steps to create a volume using Horizon dashboard.
Log into the Horizon dashboard. The Horizon dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Project tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Click Create Volume to display the dialog box.
Enter the required details in the corresponding fields.
Click Create Volume to complete the action. Clicking Cancel returns to the Volumes screen without completing the action.
The volume is successfully created and the status of the volume is available.

section.title: Delete Volume from User Account
section.p: Perform the following steps to delete a volume using Horizon dashboard:

ol.li: Log into the Horizon dashboard. The Horizon dashboard displays with the options in the left panel.
From the left panel, click the Project tab and then click the Volumes tab to display the Volumes page.
Check the box in the row of the volume to delete.
Click Delete Volume to display the dialog box.
Click Delete the Volume to confirm the deletion of the selected volume. To exit without deleting the volume and to close the screen, click Cancel before deleting.
